nodes.name: Polyethylene

nodes.name: Polypropylene
nodes.notes: Polymer detected in human liver, kidney, and brain tissues; concentrations increased from 2016 to 2024 in liver and brain.

nodes.name: Polyvinyl chloride
nodes.notes: Polymer detected in human tissues; concentrations increased from 2016 to 2024 in liver and brain and contribute to total microplastic mass.

nodes.name: Styrene-butadiene rubber
nodes.notes: Polymer detected in human brain and liver with increasing concentrations over time.

nodes.name: Polystyrene
nodes.notes: Polystyrene is one of twelve polymers quantified by Py-GC/MS standards in the tissue analysis.

nodes.name: Polyethylene terephthalate
nodes.notes: Polymer included among the twelve targeted polymers in Py-GC/MS microplastics-CaCO3 standard.

nodes.name: Poly(methyl methacrylate)
nodes.notes: Polymer included as a target in Py-GC/MS standards and detected in some tissues.

nodes.name: Polycarbonate
nodes.notes: Polymer included among quantified polymers in human tissues.

nodes.name: Polyurethane
nodes.notes: Polymer measured in human tissues by Py-GC/MS as part of the twelve-polymer panel.

nodes.name: Acrylonitrile butadiene styrene
nodes.notes: ABS resin included among the twelve polymers quantified by Py-GC/MS.

nodes.name: Nylon-6
nodes.notes: Nylon-6 detected as a component of tissue microplastics.

nodes.sample_prep: KOH digestion and ultracentrifugation as for New Mexico samples.

nodes.label: 100–200 nm nanoplastics
nodes.definition_notes: Shard- or flake-like nanoplastics with lengths largely <200 nm and widths <40 nm, observed in pellets from liver, kidney, and brain.

nodes.label: 1–5 µm microparticles
nodes.definition_notes: Rod-shaped or shard-like refractile inclusions of 1–5 µm observed in liver and kidney by microscopy; not seen in brain.

nodes.label: fragment
nodes.definition_notes: Irregular shard or flake morphology of nanoplastics in human tissues, commonly <200 nm length.
nodes.artifact_notes: Microscopy limited in resolving the smallest particles; aggregation and residual biomatrix may affect appearance.

nodes.label: brain
nodes.histology_notes: Frontal cortex parenchyma with cerebrovascular walls and immune cell infiltrates; particulate inclusions observed in parenchyma and vascular walls, especially in dementia cases.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Potential susceptibility related to blood–brain barrier integrity and clearance mechanisms; dementia cases show hallmarks like atrophy and impaired barrier.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.histology_notes: Right central liver parenchyma with refractile inclusions aggregated within regions resembling lipid droplets.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Potential aggregation of nanoplastics in hepatic lipid droplets; tissue shows carbon-rich particulate inclusions.

nodes.label: kidney
nodes.histology_notes: Wedge pieces including cortex and medulla; refractile inclusions observed in glomeruli and along tubules.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Aggregation and distribution of carbon-rich particulates in renal structures.

nodes.label: dementia
nodes.population: decedent human brain cohort with Alzheimer's disease, vascular dementia, or other dementia diagnoses
nodes.notes: Brains from decedent dementia cases showed substantially higher microplastic concentrations than normal brains; data are associative and do not establish causality.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Hypothesized mechanisms for nanoplastic uptake into the brain include clathrin-dependent endocytosis and macropinocytosis analogous to observations in Daphnia magna, and possible transport linked to lipid ingestion; routes of exposure, uptake, and clearance pathways remain poorly understood.

nodes.name: unspecified_plastic_biomarker
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: The study does not report specific molecular biomarkers such as cytokines or oxidative stress markers; primary measurements are polymer mass concentrations.

nodes.assumptions_notes: Study highlights need to understand routes of exposure and suggests that ingestion of lipids may facilitate selective nanoplastic transfer into the brain; precise pathway is not empirically characterized.

nodes.name: Low-density polyethylene
nodes.notes: Polyethylene pellets and fragments used as virgin and marine-deployed plastic in dietary exposure for medaka; pellets were 3 mm prior to grinding and <0.5 mm after grinding and sieving.

nodes.label: other

geo_context.region: University of California, Davis aquatic facility

location.region: Coronado Cays Yacht Club, San Diego Bay

nodes.sample_prep: Virgin LDPE pellets deployed in nylon mesh bags from a floating dock for 3 months; rinsed, dried, ground, sieved to <0.5 mm.
nodes.contamination_controls: Separate grinders and cleaning with acetone and hexane to avoid cross-contamination.
nodes.storage_conditions: -20 C after recovery from marine deployment.
nodes.notes: LDPE pellets deployed in San Diego Bay to sorb PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs prior to use in marine-plastic treatment diet.

nodes.sample_prep: Virgin LDPE pellets rinsed, dried, ground, sieved to <0.5 mm.
nodes.contamination_controls: Separate grinder and solvent rinsing to avoid procedural contamination.
nodes.storage_conditions: Room temperature before grinding; storage not specified after grinding.
nodes.notes: Pre-production LDPE pellets not deployed in the marine environment, used in virgin-plastic treatment diet.

nodes.sample_prep: Mixed diet with 0% plastic by weight; contained vitamin-free casein, wheat gluten, dextrin, egg albumin, soy lecithin, vitamin and mineral premix, corn oil, cod liver oil, celufil.
nodes.contamination_controls: Pre-cleaned mixing surfaces and dishes; separate from plastic diets.
nodes.storage_conditions: Prepared prior to experiment; specific storage not described.
nodes.notes: Negative control diet containing PAHs, PCBs, PBDEs from cod liver oil but no LDPE fragments.

nodes.sample_prep: As control diet but with 10% by weight ground virgin LDPE substituted for dextrin.
nodes.contamination_controls: Separate pre-cleaned dishes for each diet; mixed on pre-cleaned surfaces.
nodes.storage_conditions: Prepared before 2-month exposure; storage not specified.
nodes.notes: Virgin-plastic treatment diet containing ground LDPE fragments (~0.5 mm) and background PAHs, PCBs, PBDEs.

nodes.sample_prep: As control diet but with 10% by weight ground LDPE deployed 3 months in San Diego Bay, sieved to <0.5 mm.
nodes.contamination_controls: Separate dishes; pre-cleaned equipment; activated charcoal filters in tank system to limit background contamination.
nodes.storage_conditions: Prepared before exposure; storage not specified.
nodes.notes: Marine-plastic treatment diet exposing fish to higher concentrations of PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs via sorbed contaminants on LDPE.

nodes.sample_prep: Three replicate water samples collected post-experiment for PBT analysis.
nodes.contamination_controls: Activated charcoal filters used and changed twice per month; LDPE not allowed into recirculating system during feedings.
nodes.notes: No detectable PBTs in post-experiment tank water, suggesting diet was primary exposure route.

nodes.sample_prep: Pooled ~14 medaka per tank to obtain 5 g tissue sample at 1-month; prepared for PAH, PCB, PBDE analysis.
nodes.contamination_controls: Standard QA/QC in chemical analysis; details in supplementary methods.
nodes.storage_conditions: Fish euthanized with MS-222 before sampling; tissue handling per toxicology protocols.
nodes.notes: Used to quantify early bioaccumulation of PAHs, PCBs, PBDEs after 1 month of dietary exposure.

nodes.sample_prep: Three pooled 5 g samples per tank at 2 months, prepared for PAH, PCB, PBDE analysis.
nodes.contamination_controls: QA/QC as described in supplementary methods; ANOVA performed on log-transformed data.
nodes.storage_conditions: Fish euthanized with MS-222; tissues processed for chemical analysis.
nodes.notes: Used to quantify bioaccumulation of PBTs after 2-month chronic exposure; showed higher PBDE levels in marine-plastic group.

nodes.sample_prep: Livers from six male and six female medaka per tank pooled by sex, total RNA isolated, DNase treated, cDNA synthesized for RT-qPCR.
nodes.contamination_controls: Multiple reference genes used (GAPDH, β-actin, 18S rRNA); Ct values averaged from triplicates.
nodes.storage_conditions: Livers stored at -80 C prior to RNA extraction.
nodes.notes: Used to assess hepatic CYP1A gene expression after 1 and 2 months of exposure.

nodes.sample_prep: Eight fish per tank fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin, dehydrated, paraffin embedded, 3 µm sections stained with hematoxylin and eosin.
nodes.contamination_controls: Standard histological processing; some fish lost due to methodological error.
nodes.storage_conditions: Fixed and embedded samples stored under standard histology conditions.
nodes.notes: Used to score liver histopathology including glycogen depletion, fatty vacuolation, single-cell necrosis, and neoplastic lesions at 2 months.

nodes.label: fragment
nodes.definition_notes: Irregular particles produced by grinding LDPE pellets and sieving to <0.5 mm; observed in medaka gastrointestinal tract and feces during exposure.
nodes.artifact_notes: Ground in laboratory; care taken to avoid contamination but fragmentation is artificial relative to environmental mechanical breakdown.

nodes.label: <0.5 mm_fragments
nodes.definition_notes: Size class corresponding to LDPE fragments collected using sieves to obtain particles smaller than 0.5 mm for dietary exposure.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Chronic ingestion of LDPE with sorbed PBTs leads to hepatic stress including glycogen depletion, fatty vacuolation, necrosis and neoplastic lesions indicating complex toxic mechanisms including metabolic disturbance and possibly oxidative stress.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.histology_notes: Livers showed severe glycogen depletion, fatty vacuolation, single-cell necrosis, eosinophilic focus of cellular alteration and hepatocellular adenoma in fish exposed to virgin and marine LDPE diets.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Central organ for metabolism and detoxification of xenobiotics; hepatic damage may hinder detoxification mechanisms including AhR-mediated responses.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Site of plastic ingestion and initial contact with LDPE fragments and sorbed contaminants; plastic observed in gastrointestinal tract.

nodes.name: CYP1A mRNA expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Expected to increase after exposure to PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs via AhR activation, but no significant treatment-related differences were observed after 1 or 2 months at the exposure conditions used.

nodes.name: hepatic glycogen depletion
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Severe glycogen depletion observed in a high proportion of fish exposed to LDPE diets, particularly marine-plastic treatment, indicates hepatic metabolic stress linked to exposure to organochlorinated xenobiotics.

nodes.name: hepatic fatty vacuolation
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Fatty vacuolar degeneration in liver cells indicates potential progression to fatty liver degeneration associated with exposure to contaminants such as PCBs.

nodes.name: single-cell hepatocellular necrosis
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Presence of single-cell necrosis in livers of fish exposed to marine LDPE diet indicates cytotoxic injury associated with plastic and sorbed contaminants.

nodes.name: preneoplastic and neoplastic hepatic lesions
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Observation of eosinophilic focus of cellular alteration and hepatocellular adenoma in exposed fish suggests early carcinogenic processes related to plastic exposure; such lesions are rare in young medaka without exposure.

nodes.label: hepatic_toxicity
nodes.notes: Chronic dietary exposure to LDPE, particularly marine-deployed LDPE with sorbed PBTs, induces hepatic toxicity in medaka, evidenced by histological liver damage and lesion formation.

nodes.label: liver_tumor
nodes.notes: A hepatocellular adenoma occupying 25% of the liver observed in one fish from the marine-plastic treatment, and a preneoplastic eosinophilic focus in a virgin-plastic fish, indicate potential tumorigenic outcomes from chronic plastic ingestion.

nodes.intake_metric: percent_plastic_in_diet (10% by weight; ~0.3 mg plastic per feeding, 2% body weight per day; 8 ng plastic/mL water equivalent)
nodes.population_context: adult Japanese medaka in laboratory tanks
nodes.assumptions_notes: Fish exposed to LDPE fragments mixed into diet; plastic and diet separate in water column, mimicking floating plastic exposure; chronic 2-month exposure.

nodes.label: PBT_concentrations_on_marine_LDPE
nodes.notes: Marine-deployed LDPE pellets accumulated higher concentrations of PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs than virgin LDPE pellets.

nodes.label: PBT_concentrations_in_treatment_diets
nodes.notes: Marine-plastic and virgin-plastic treatment diets showed higher total PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs than control diet; marine-plastic diet particularly enriched in PCBs and PBDEs.

nodes.label: PBT_body_burden_after_2_months
nodes.notes: Medaka exposed to marine-plastic diet had greater concentrations of total PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs than control fish after 2 months; PBDEs and specific congeners (chrysene, PCB28) significantly higher.

nodes.label: hepatic_CYP1A_expression_patterns
nodes.notes: No significant differences in CYP1A expression among treatments for males or females after 1 or 2 months, despite exposure to PBTs.

nodes.label: liver_histopathological_changes
nodes.notes: Higher prevalence of severe glycogen depletion, fatty vacuolation, single-cell necrosis, preneoplastic lesion and hepatocellular adenoma in fish exposed to LDPE diets compared to control.

attributes.description: Microplastic particles (5–10 μm, spheric or irregular, pigmented) found in 4 human placentas: 5 in the fetal side, 4 in the maternal side, 3 in the chorioamniotic membranes; three particles identified as stained polypropylene, nine with pigments used in coatings, paints, adhesives, plasters, finger paints, polymers, cosmetics and personal care products.

nodes.name: Polystyrene
nodes.notes: Polystyrene nanoplastics of nominal primary size ~25 nm and density 1.05 g/cm3 were used as fluorescently labelled particles in larval zebrafish exposure experiments.

nodes.sample_prep: Larval zebrafish were exposed individually in 24- or 48-well plates containing defined volumes of egg water with suspended PSNPs, with medium exchange once during exposure.
nodes.contamination_controls: Particle control experiment using TiO2 nanoparticles matched by particle number to PSNPs; solvent controls for mifepristone and glucose were included.
nodes.storage_conditions: Larvae maintained at 28.5±0.5 °C in incubators with defined light–dark cycles until sampling; specific storage conditions for post-collection samples varied by assay.
nodes.collector: Institute of Environmental Sciences (CML), Leiden University
nodes.notes: Embryos and larvae (Danio rerio) were exposed from 72 to 120 h post-fertilisation in egg water with polystyrene nanoplastics, with additional co-exposures to glucose and mifepristone in some assays.

nodes.label: nanoplastic_approx_25_nm
nodes.definition_notes: Nominal hydrodynamic diameter of polystyrene nanoplastic particles in egg water was approximately 19–25 nm as assessed by TEM and DLS in previous work referenced in the study.

nodes.label: other
nodes.definition_notes: Polystyrene nanoplastics were supplied as nominally spherical nanoparticles.

nodes.label: other

emission_rate_estimate.context: Nominal highest exposure concentration in egg water from 72 to 120 hpf for PSNPs.

nodes.notes: Fluorescent polystyrene nanoplastics were intentionally added to exposure media to model nanoplastic exposure; they are a primary micro/nanoplastic source rather than degradation products.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.histology_notes: Includes gastrointestinal tract of larvae at 72–120 hpf where PSNP accumulation was observed in the intestine lumen and epithelium.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Gastrointestinal tract serves as major accumulation and potential translocation site for nanoplastics following ingestion.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.histology_notes: Hepatic tissue is involved in glucose and lipid metabolism; gene expression markers such as fgf21, g6pca, ldha were measured in whole larvae, reflecting hepatic metabolic regulation.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Liver is a key metabolic organ sensitive to nanoplastic-induced disruption of energy metabolism.

nodes.label: other
nodes.histology_notes: Exocrine and endocrine pancreas in developing zebrafish are closely associated; PSNP accumulation was reported in the exocrine pancreas, and insulin-expressing endocrine pancreas was assessed by in situ hybridisation.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Pancreatic tissues regulating insulin secretion and digestion are implicated in nanoplastic-induced alterations of glucose homeostasis.

nodes.label: brain
nodes.histology_notes: Brain receives signals related to glucose status and cortisol, integrating HPI-axis activation and behavioural outputs such as locomotor activity during dark challenges.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Neural circuits mediating stress and locomotor responses may be affected indirectly via cortisol and metabolic disruption in PSNP-exposed larvae.

nodes.label: blood
nodes.histology_notes: Whole-body homogenates used for glucose and cortisol quantification integrate contributions from circulating blood and tissues.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Circulating cortisol and glucose levels reflect systemic stress and metabolic status during PSNP exposure.

nodes.label: metabolic_disturbance
nodes.notes: Polystyrene nanoplastic exposure decreased whole-body glucose levels, altered expression of gluconeogenic (pck1, g6pca) and metabolic regulators (fgf21, ldha), and reduced insulin-expressing domain size, indicating disruption of glucose homeostasis and energy metabolism.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: PSNP exposure increased whole-body cortisol levels in wild-type larvae in a dose-dependent manner and downregulated expression of the serotonin transporter gene slc6a4, suggesting HPI-axis activation and potential neuromodulatory changes.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: A bottom-up chain of events was proposed where PSNP accumulation in pancreas and gut reduces glucose, which stimulates cortisol secretion through glucocorticoid receptor activation and leads to altered locomotor behaviour under dark challenge.

nodes.name: glucose
nodes.threshold_unit: mg/L PSNP (nominal exposure concentration associated with significant decrease)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased glucose levels indicate disruption of energy metabolism and may act as a trigger for stress-axis activation.

nodes.name: cortisol
nodes.threshold_unit: mg/L PSNP (lowest concentration with significant increase)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Elevated cortisol is a hallmark of stress response in fish and is implicated in modulation of behaviour and metabolism.

nodes.name: pck1 promoter activity
nodes.tissue_matrix: whole larval zebrafish with liver- and kidney-localised promoter activity
nodes.threshold_unit: mg/L PSNP (lowest tested with increased activity)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase 1 promoter activity reflects enhanced gluconeogenesis in response to disrupted glucose homeostasis.

nodes.name: g6pca (glucose-6-phosphatase a) expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Upregulated glucose-6-phosphatase indicates activation of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenic processes.

nodes.name: fgf21 expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Fibroblast growth factor 21 plays a role in hepatic lipid and glucose homeostasis; increased expression suggests altered metabolic regulation.

nodes.name: ldha expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Reduced lactate dehydrogenase a expression points to altered anaerobic glycolysis under PSNP exposure.

nodes.name: slc6a4 expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Downregulation of serotonin transporter (slc6a4) suggests altered serotonergic signalling that may contribute to behavioural changes.

nodes.name: insulin expression domain size
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Reduced insulin-expressing area in the pancreas indicates impaired endocrine function associated with disturbed glucose regulation.

nodes.label: locomotor_hyperactivity_dark_challenge
nodes.population: larval zebrafish (wild-type ABTL and gr strains) exposed from 72–120 hpf
nodes.notes: PSNP-exposed wild-type larvae exhibited increased distance moved during dark challenge phases in an alternating light–dark test, whereas this hyperactivity was absent in glucocorticoid receptor mutant larvae and under glucose co-exposure or mifepristone treatment.

nodes.label: reduced_swim_bladder_inflation
nodes.population: larval zebrafish (wild-type and gr mutants) exposed from 72–120 hpf
nodes.notes: A lower proportion of PSNP-exposed larvae had inflated swim bladders compared to controls, suggesting developmental effects on swim bladder inflation independent of glucocorticoid receptor activity.

nodes.population_context: developing zebrafish larvae in laboratory conditions
nodes.assumptions_notes: Exposure initiated post-hatching at 72 hpf to avoid chorion barrier, with ingestion and epithelial contact in egg water containing suspended PSNPs; particles also contact outer epithelia early in development.

nodes.notes: Observation of PSNP biodistribution showing accumulation in intestine, exocrine pancreas, and gallbladder after exposure from 72 to 120 hpf.
Increased whole-body cortisol levels in wild-type larvae exposed to PSNPs in a dose-dependent manner, not observed in glucocorticoid receptor mutants or under glucose co-exposure.
Decreased whole-body glucose levels at the highest PSNP exposure concentration, with strain- and treatment-dependent modulation by glucocorticoid receptor status and mifepristone co-exposure.
Dose-dependent increase in pck1 promoter-driven luciferase activity with PSNP exposure, partially suppressed by glucocorticoid receptor antagonist mifepristone.
qPCR-based changes in expression of metabolic and serotonin-related genes (g6pca, fgf21 upregulated; ldha and slc6a4 downregulated) after PSNP exposure.
Reduction in size of insulin expression domain in PSNP-exposed larvae as shown by in situ hybridisation.

PSNP-exposed wild-type larvae showed increased distance moved during dark challenges, whereas particle control TiO2, glucocorticoid receptor mutants, and glucose or mifepristone co-exposures did not show this hyperactivity.

nodes.label: brain
nodes.histology_notes: Prefrontal cortex (PFC) examined for neuronal morphology, Nissl bodies, synapses, and mitochondrial ultrastructure.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: PFC implicated in executive function and memory; studied as a target of PS-NPs-induced neurotoxicity.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: blood
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Blood-brain barrier permeability to PS-NPs mentioned as enabling nanoplastics to reach CNS.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: PS-NPs exposure decreased GSH and SOD levels and reduced Nrf2-positive cells in PFC, consistent with oxidative stress; NAC treatment reversed these effects.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: In SH-SY5Y cells, PS-NPs decreased GSH and SOD; NAC co-treatment restored antioxidant markers.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Neuronal cuproptosis characterized by increased cerebral copper, upregulated FDX1, LIAS, DLAT, HSP70, reduced lipoylated DLAT and its oligomerization, and mitochondrial damage in PFC after PS-NPs exposure.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: PS-NPs induced cuproptosis-like changes in SH-SY5Y cells with increased cuprous copper and altered cuproptosis markers; effects mitigated by copper chelator TTM and NAC.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Oxidative stress-activated ERK-MAPK signaling contributes to PS-NPs-induced cuproptosis in SH-SY5Y cells; ERK inhibitor PD98059 reduced p-ERK, normalized cuproptosis markers, and improved cell viability.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: In PFC, PS-NPs exposure activated ERK-MAPK signaling (increased p-ERK); NAC treatment reduced ERK phosphorylation and attenuated cuproptosis-associated changes.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: GSH
nodes.assay_type: Commercial glutathione assay kit (Beyotime, China) in tissue homogenates and cell lysates.
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse brain/PFC homogenate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decrease indicates oxidative stress associated with PS-NPs exposure; NAC restored GSH levels in vivo and in vitro.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: SOD activity
nodes.assay_type: Commercial superoxide dismutase assay kit (Beyotime, China).
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse brain/PFC homogenate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Reduced SOD activity reflects oxidative stress in brain and neuronal cells after PS-NPs exposure; NAC reversed SOD depletion.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: Nrf2-positive cell count
nodes.assay_type: Immunohistochemistry for Nrf2 in PFC sections.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased Nrf2 staining after PS-NPs exposure indicates impaired antioxidant response; NAC increased Nrf2-positive cells.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: Tissue copper content
nodes.assay_type: Copper content assay kit measuring absorbance at 580 nm.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased cerebral copper after PS-NPs exposure associated with neuronal cuproptosis; NAC reduced copper levels.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: Intracellular cuprous copper (Cu+)
nodes.assay_type: Cuprous content fluorescence assay (ex 395 nm, em 480 nm).
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: PS-NPs increased intracellular Cu+, indicating copper redox imbalance; NAC and TTM reduced Cu+.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: FDX1 protein level
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Upregulated FDX1 indicates activation of copper-dependent lipoylation pathway in cuproptosis.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: LIAS protein level
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased LIAS supports enhanced lipoylation activity associated with cuproptosis.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: DLAT protein and lipoylated DLAT oligomers
nodes.assay_type: Western blot and immunofluorescence for DLAT and lipoylated DLAT.
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate and sections; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: PS-NPs increased total DLAT and caused oligomerization with decreased monomeric lipoylated DLAT, a hallmark of cuproptosis; NAC and PD98059 reduced oligomerization.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: HSP70 protein level
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Elevated HSP70 reflects proteotoxic stress associated with cuproptosis after PS-NPs exposure.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: p-ERK/ERK ratio
nodes.assay_type: Western blot for ERK and phospho-ERK.
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased ERK phosphorylation indicates activation of ERK-MAPK signaling; NAC and PD98059 reduced p-ERK levels, linking ERK activation to oxidative stress and cuproptosis.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: SLC31A1 mRNA
nodes.tissue_matrix: SH-SY5Y cells; PFC transcript levels reported.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Upregulation of copper transporter SLC31A1 mRNA suggests enhanced copper influx contributing to cuproptosis in PS-NPs-exposed cells.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: Neuronal viability (CCK-8 absorbance)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased absorbance indicates PS-NPs-induced cytotoxicity; rescued by NAC, TTM, and PD98059, consistent with oxidative stress, copper overload, and ERK-MAPK-mediated cuproptosis.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: Synapse number and PSD thickness
nodes.assay_type: TEM with quantitative morphometry using ImageJ.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: PS-NPs reduced synapse number and postsynaptic density thickness; NAC co-treatment increased both metrics, linking synaptic integrity to cognitive outcomes.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: Nissl body count, normal neuron density
nodes.assay_type: HE and Nissl staining with ImageJ quantification.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: PS-NPs reduced number of normal neurons and Nissl bodies; NAC increased neuronal counts and Nissl density, indicating protection against neuropathological damage.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.assumptions_notes: Mice gavaged daily with 12.5 mg/kg/day 60 nm PS-NPs for 30 days; dose derived from human equivalent microplastics intake scaling based on body surface area.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.assumptions_notes: Cells exposed to PS-NPs at 0.25–0.75 mg/mL for 24 h in culture medium to model neuronal exposure to nanoplastics.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: cognitive_impairment
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology
nodes.notes: PS-NPs exposure impaired learning and memory in mice as shown by reduced novel object preference index, decreased Y-maze alternation rate, longer escape latency, and fewer platform crossings and shorter time in target quadrant in Morris water maze; NAC mitigated these deficits.

nodes.label: neurotoxicity
nodes.population: C57BL/6 male mice and SH-SY5Y neuronal cells
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology
nodes.notes: Composite outcome including neuronal loss, decreased Nissl bodies, synaptic degeneration, mitochondrial damage, oxidative stress, and reduced cell viability attributable to PS-NPs exposure.

nodes.label: synaptic_dysfunction
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology
nodes.notes: PS-NPs exposure reduced synapse number and postsynaptic density thickness in PFC; NAC increased synaptic metrics, suggesting functional synaptic impairment and rescue.

nodes.label: neuronal_cell_death
nodes.population: C57BL/6 male mice and SH-SY5Y neuronal cells
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology
nodes.notes: PS-NPs induced neuronal loss in PFC and reduced SH-SY5Y viability; linked mechanistically to cuproptosis via copper dyshomeostasis and ERK-MAPK activation.

nodes.notes: Decreased rate of algal consumption after nanoparticle accumulation in the gut, not statistically significant over 6 h but indicative of possible longer-term effects.

attributes.description: Daphnia-conditioned medium contains proteins up to ~435 µg/mL at 6 h, leading to increased hydrodynamic size and polydispersity of NH2-PS NPs and destabilization/agglomeration.

COOH-PS NPs incubated in Daphnia-conditioned medium show decreased EC50 for survival (0.0363 to 0.0337 mg/mL at 6 h conditioning; to 0.0095 mg/mL after longer incubation), and NH2-PS NPs show similar EC50 decreases with conditioning and incubation.

Fluorescent COOH-PS NPs are taken up into Daphnia magna neonates in a time-dependent manner and remain confined to the gut; ~15% of dose remains after 6 h post-exposure for unconditioned NPs and ~20% for eco-corona-coated NPs.
Daphnia magna neonates previously exposed to eco-corona-coated COOH-PS NPs show a trend towards reduced feeding on algae over 6 h compared to controls.

attributes.name: Polystyrene
attributes.notes: Frequently used in toxicity studies on fetoplacental unit and reproductive system; polystyrene microplastics (MPs) and nanoplastics (NPs) reported in animal and ex vivo human placental models.

attributes.name: Polyethylene
attributes.notes: Common microplastic polymer; PE microplastics (10–45 μm) reported to accumulate in fetal kidneys in mice.

attributes.definition_notes: Nanopolystyrene particles (20–500 nm) reported in fetal liver, heart, brain, lung and kidney after maternal exposure in rodents and in ex vivo human placental perfusion experiments.
Fragments sized 5–10 μm detected in human placental tissues on maternal side, fetal side and chorioamniotic membranes.
General definition of microplastics as particles <5 mm; review synthesizes effects of such particles on the fetoplacental unit and reproductive systems.
Microbeads used in exfoliants, toothpaste and cosmetic products; bead-like particles also described in human placenta.
attributes.artifact_notes: Fluorescent polystyrene beads may introduce artifacts in placental translocation studies.

attributes.definition_notes: Fibers are a common morphology of microplastics originating from textiles and indoor sources.
Irregular fragments reported as common environmental microplastic shapes and detected in human placental tissue.

emission_rate_estimate.context: Synthetic fibers released during washing clothing made of acrylic, fleece and polyester.

attributes.notes: Textile washing is a major primary source of microfibers entering wastewater and the environment.

emission_rate_estimate.context: Microbeads in exfoliants, toothpaste and hygiene products discharged to wastewater.

attributes.notes: Microbeads in personal care products introduce large numbers of microplastics per use.

emission_rate_estimate.context: Microplastics produced from tire deterioration per kilometer driven.

attributes.notes: Tire dust and related uses contribute substantially to microplastic pollution.

emission_rate_estimate.context: Indirect contamination of soils via sludge land application and irrigation with treated or untreated wastewater.

attributes.notes: Wastewater and sludge application introduce microplastics to terrestrial compartments.

nodes.label: Ingestion of contaminated food and drinking water

attributes.assumptions_notes: Includes direct ingestion via microplastic-contaminated water, salt and food (e.g., seafood) and indirect trophic transfer.
Airborne microplastics present in indoor and outdoor air can be inhaled and reach lungs, then potentially systemic circulation.
Plastic particles in maternal blood or tissues can cross the placental barrier and reach the fetoplacental unit and fetal organs.

attributes.notes: Micro- and nanoplastics induce ROS overproduction and oxidative damage in placental and reproductive tissues, disrupting nutrient/oxygen transfer and organ function.

attributes.species_scope: mice; rats; zebrafish; human placenta models
attributes.notes: Plastic particles trigger inflammatory responses in testes, ovaries and placental tissues, including activation of NF-κB pathway and inflammasome components.

attributes.species_scope: rodents; human observational evidence for endocrine-disrupting chemicals on plastics
attributes.notes: Endocrine-disrupting chemicals associated with plastics can interfere with hormone signaling essential for reproduction and fetal development.
Microplastic exposure can alter DNA methylation and histone modifications, producing epigenetic changes in stress and developmental pathways.
Maternal polystyrene microplastic exposure altered metabolic homeostasis and lipid profiles in F1 and F2 offspring.
Microplastics may impair immune cell trafficking and chemokine receptor function at the maternal–fetal interface, affecting tolerance and vascular remodeling.

attributes.histology_notes: Hemochorial organ at the fetomaternal interface; syncytiotrophoblast layer participates in selective transfer and accumulation of polystyrene particles.
attributes.vulnerability_notes: Limited detoxification capacity and unique immune regulation make placenta particularly sensitive to micro- and nanoplastics.
Nanopolystyrene reported to deposit in fetal liver following maternal exposure.
Nanopolystyrene detected in fetal brain; neurodevelopmental impacts are of concern.
Fetal kidney accumulation observed for PE microplastics 10–45 μm.

attributes.histology_notes: Testicular germinal epithelium, germ cells, Sertoli and Leydig cells are affected.
attributes.vulnerability_notes: PS MPs and NPs impair spermatogenesis, sperm morphology and hormone production.

attributes.histology_notes: Granulosa cells and ovarian follicles are altered following PS MPs exposure.
attributes.vulnerability_notes: Reduced follicle number, oxidative stress and pyroptosis/apoptosis observed in granulosa cells.
Microplastics detected in human blood; can serve as transport medium to placenta and organs.

attributes.name: Reactive oxygen species
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Overproduction of ROS is a central mechanism linking microplastic exposure to oxidative damage in placenta and reproductive tissues.

attributes.name: Malondialdehyde
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased MDA indicates lipid peroxidation associated with oxidative stress after PS MPs exposure.

attributes.name: Glutathione peroxidase
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased antioxidant enzyme activity reflects impaired redox defense following microplastic exposure.

attributes.name: NF-κB p65 (and phosphorylated p65)
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased NF-κB signaling indicates activation of inflammatory pathways in testes after PS MPs exposure.

attributes.name: Interleukin-6
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Pro-inflammatory cytokine elevated in reproductive toxicity models with PS MPs/NPs.

attributes.name: Nrf2
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Downregulation of Nrf2/HO-1 antioxidant pathway suggests compromised antioxidant response.

attributes.name: Testosterone
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Reduced testosterone linked to impaired spermatogenesis in male mice exposed to PS MPs.

attributes.name: Luteinizing hormone
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased LH levels reported with PS NPs exposure in male rats, with nonlinear responses at high doses.

attributes.name: Follicle-stimulating hormone
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Altered FSH reflects disruption of hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal axis.

attributes.name: Anti-Müllerian hormone
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Reduced AMH levels indicate diminished ovarian reserve in female rats exposed to PS MPs.

attributes.notes: Includes infertility, altered spermatogenesis, ovarian reserve reduction and other reproductive anomalies associated with MNP exposure.

attributes.population: workers in plastics sector; animal models
attributes.notes: Occupational data and animal experiments suggest increased infertility risk with plastic exposure.
Potential developmental abnormalities from disrupted placental function and fetal exposure to MNPs.
Review suggests placental immune and vascular disruptions by microplastics may contribute to preeclampsia.
Impaired nutrient and oxygen exchange due to microplastics in placenta may increase risk of growth restriction.
Fetal brain exposure and oxidative stress may affect long-term behavior and cognition.

attributes.population: F1 and F2 offspring of exposed dams
attributes.notes: Maternal PS MPs exposure altered lipid profiles and metabolic homeostasis in offspring.

nodes.label: Ex vivo human placental perfusion model

attributes.notes: Placental tissues from maternal side, fetal side and chorioamniotic membranes analyzed for MPs.
Lung tissue examined for microplastics using μFTIR.
Male mice exposed to PS MPs/NPs; testes collected for spermatogenesis and biomarker analysis.
Female Wistar rats exposed to PS MPs; ovarian granulosa cells analyzed.

nodes.label: Detection of microplastics in human placenta

attributes.description: Twelve microplastic fragments of 5–10 μm detected in human placentas on maternal side, fetal side and membranes; polypropylene common.
Polystyrene nanoplastics of 20–500 nm detected in fetal liver, brain, lung, heart and kidney after maternal exposure in rodent models.

nodes.label: PS MPs bioaccumulate in mouse testes and disrupt spermatogenesis

attributes.description: PS MPs of 0.5–10 μm accumulated in mouse testes, altered spermatogenesis, sperm morphology, testosterone, body weight and induced inflammation.

nodes.label: PS MPs induce oxidative stress and cell death in rat ovary

attributes.description: PS MPs exposure reduced developing follicles, decreased GSH-Px, CAT, SOD, increased MDA, NLRP3, IL-1β, IL-18 and granulosa cell death.

attributes.name: polyethylene
attributes.notes: Polyethylene detected in multiple human samples including lungs, liver, placenta, feces and blood.

attributes.assumptions_notes: Includes microplastics from drinking water, seafood, and terrestrial animal products as described in intake estimates. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
Includes environmental and occupational airborne exposure leading to chronic inhalation of fibers and particles.

attributes.notes: Microplastics exposure in animals increases oxidative stress and affects energy and lipid metabolism. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Respiratory exposure to polystyrene particles increased inflammatory proteins such as TNF-α. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

Review cited in the paper concludes that microplastics, especially nanoplastics, can cross the blood–brain barrier and affect acetylcholinesterase activity and behavior. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

attributes.name: TNF-α
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased after inhalation exposure to 0.10 µm polystyrene in rats, indicating inflammatory response in the lungs. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

attributes.name: acetylcholinesterase_activity

attributes.name: oxidative_stress_markers
attributes.clinical_relevance_notes: Microplastics exposure increased oxidative stress in animal studies.

attributes.notes: Occupational exposure to airborne microplastics in plastic and textile industries is associated with airway and lung disease. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

Increased heart weight observed after inhalation exposure to 0.10 µm polystyrene in rats.
Review cited reports that microplastics can reach the brain and alter neurotransmitters and behavior.

attributes.definition_notes: Microplastics are defined as particles smaller than 5 mm in this review.

Fragmentation of littered plastic waste and larger plastics into secondary microplastics.

Small intestine around Peyer’s patches is a main site of particle internalization via enterocytes and persorption.
Key organ for clearance of circulating microplastics via Kupffer cells and biliary excretion; higher microplastics levels found in cirrhotic livers.
Microplastics accumulated in kidneys in some animal exposure studies.
Microplastics have been detected in human placental tissue.
Microplastics and nanoplastics can cross the blood–brain barrier and alter acetylcholinesterase activity and neurotransmitters.
Microplastics have been detected in human blood using pyrolysis–GC–MS and are rapidly cleared by liver and spleen.

Lower airway bronchoalveolar lavage samples analyzed for microplastics.
Human blood samples analyzed using pyrolysis–GC–MS for polymer mass concentrations.

nodes.name: polyethylene
nodes.notes: One of the top three polymer types reported in marine microplastics; also used as barium-labelled microplastic beads in a human GI transit study.

nodes.name: polyethylene_terephthalate
nodes.notes: Reported as the most common plastic type in some commercial sea salts.

nodes.label: fiber
nodes.definition_notes: Frequently observed morphology of microplastics in seafood, honey, beer and table salt.
nodes.artifact_notes: Airborne fibres can contaminate samples if quality assurance is insufficient.

nodes.label: fragment
nodes.definition_notes: Irregular pieces derived from fragmentation of larger plastic items.

nodes.label: bead
nodes.definition_notes: Spherical particles used in cosmetic formulations and as engineered microplastic beads.
nodes.artifact_notes: Used experimentally as barium-labelled polyethylene beads in a human GI transit study.

nodes.label: film
nodes.definition_notes: Thin plastic sheets; film particles reported in seafood and beach litter studies.

nodes.label: foam
nodes.definition_notes: Foamed plastics observed among ingested particles in some fish.

nodes.label: microplastics_0.1_5000_micrometer
nodes.definition_notes: Working definition in the EFSA statement: heterogeneous mixture of materials (fragments, fibres, spheroids, granules, pellets, flakes or beads) in the range 0.1–5,000 µm.

nodes.label: nanoplastics_0.001_0.1_micrometer
nodes.definition_notes: Defined in line with nanomaterial definitions as particles with at least one dimension in the 1–100 nm (0.001–0.1 µm) range.

nodes.label: small_microplastics_lt_150_micrometer
nodes.definition_notes: Subset of microplastics (<150 µm) highlighted because only particles below this size may translocate across the gut epithelium and are emphasised for exposure and toxicokinetic research.

nodes.label: very_small_microplastics_lt_1.5_micrometer
nodes.definition_notes: Microplastic fraction <1.5 µm noted as capable of penetrating deeply into organs after oral uptake.

nodes.label: personal_care
nodes.notes: Primary microplastics from personal care products such as toothpaste, cleaning agents and cosmetic microbeads that enter sewer systems and subsequently the marine environment.

nodes.label: textiles
nodes.notes: Microplastic fibres released from clothes during washing; transported via sewer systems that do not fully remove these particles before discharge to the marine environment.

nodes.label: pellets
nodes.notes: Virgin resin pellets and industrial scrubbers used in blasting and moulding processes; classified as primary microplastics.

nodes.label: paint
nodes.notes: Paints identified as a land-based source of secondary microplastics entering the marine environment.

nodes.label: tire_wear
nodes.notes: Tyres described as another source of secondary microplastics released to the environment.

nodes.title: Marine Strategy Framework Directive (Directive 2008/56/EC)
nodes.scope: Framework directive aiming at Good Environmental Status of EU marine waters by 2020; Descriptor 10 covers marine litter including microplastics (properties and quantities of marine litter should not cause harm).
nodes.compliance_requirements: Member States must monitor trends in the amount, distribution and, where possible, composition of marine litter, including micro-particles, and litter ingested by marine animals.

nodes.title: Microbead-Free Waters Act of 2015
nodes.scope: US federal law banning manufacture and sale of rinse-off cosmetics containing intentionally added plastic microbeads on specified dates, including products that are over-the-counter drugs.
nodes.compliance_requirements: Prohibits manufacture and sale of specified cosmetic products containing plastic microbeads according to phased deadlines.

nodes.assumptions_notes: Pathway from microplastics in marine seafood (e.g., mussels) to human oral exposure; example calculation uses 225 g mussel portion with 900 microplastic pieces (~7 µg plastic).
Exposure via other foods reported to contain microplastics such as honey, beer and table salt, where concentrations are expressed as fibres, fragments or particles per g or mL.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.histology_notes: Gastrointestinal (GI) tract is the primary contact site for ingested microplastics and nanoplastics.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Only microplastics smaller than 150 µm may translocate across the gut epithelium (limited absorption ≤0.3%); the smallest fraction (<1.5 µm) may penetrate more deeply into organs. Local effects in the GI tract and microbiota remain largely unknown and are highlighted as a research need.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Liver damage is mentioned as one of several toxic effects observed for engineered nanomaterials (metal and metal oxide particles), not specifically for nanoplastics; extrapolation to nanoplastics requires caution.

nodes.label: kidney
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Kidney damage is also reported among toxic effects of engineered nanomaterials; specific data for nanoplastics are lacking and risk cannot currently be evaluated.

nodes.label: marine_microplastic_polymer_profile
nodes.notes: Observation that the top three polymer types reported in marine microplastics are polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP) and polystyrene.

nodes.label: mussel_portion_microplastic_exposure_example
nodes.notes: Calculated exposure scenario for a 225 g mussel portion using the highest microplastic levels found in mussels: 900 particles per portion, equivalent to about 7 µg of plastic assuming 25 µm spherical particles with density 0.92 g/cm3.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_various_foods
nodes.notes: Occurrence of microplastics reported in seafood (fish, shrimp, bivalves) and in other foods including honey, beer and table salt, with results expressed as particles per individual or per unit mass/volume.
Commercially relevant fish and bivalves (e.g., mussels, oysters, clams, sardines, sprats) reported to contain microplastics in edible tissues.
Canned sardines and sprats shown to contain micro- and mesoplastics.
Bottled mineral water where microplastics are released from packaging into water.
Table salts from marine origin reported to contain microplastics.
Honey and sugar samples shown to contain non-pollen particulates including microplastics.

nodes.name: Polyethylene

nodes.name: Polystyrene
nodes.notes: Polystyrene micro- and nanoparticles and associated styrene oligomers reported in marine sand and seawater and in toxicology studies.

nodes.label: fiber
nodes.definition_notes: Secondary microplastics derived from fabric and rope; airborne fibers are a major inhalation source.

nodes.label: fragment
nodes.definition_notes: Fragments from degradation of larger plastic items.

nodes.label: bead
nodes.definition_notes: Primary microplastics intentionally manufactured as microbeads in cosmetics and toothpaste.

nodes.label: 0.3–10 µm_polyethylene_particles
nodes.definition_notes: Polyethylene particles in the 0.3–10 µm range shown to stimulate cytokine production in vitro.

nodes.label: textiles
nodes.notes: Synthetic textiles release airborne microplastic fibers that contribute to inhalation exposure.

nodes.label: tire_wear
nodes.notes: Powdered synthetic rubber tires and city dust are major sources of airborne microplastics.

nodes.label: pellets
nodes.notes: Preproduction resin pellets are a primary microplastic form entering marine environments.

nodes.label: personal_care
nodes.notes: Microbeads in cosmetics and toothpaste are primary microplastics that can enter aquatic systems.

nodes.name: IL-6
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Pro-inflammatory cytokine increased after exposure to plastic particles.

nodes.name: IL-1b
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Pro-inflammatory cytokine increased by polyethylene particles (0.3–10 µm).

nodes.name: TNF-a
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Pro-inflammatory cytokine stimulated by polyethylene particles.

nodes.name: superoxide_dismutase
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Antioxidant enzyme activity increased, indicating oxidative stress after microplastic exposure in zebrafish.

nodes.name: catalase
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Antioxidant enzyme activity increased in zebrafish exposed to micro- and nano-sized plastics.

nodes.name: inhibin_B
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Lower serum inhibin B associated with higher urinary BPA in men, indicating impaired male reproductive hormone status.

nodes.name: estradiol_to_testosterone_ratio
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Estradiol:testosterone ratio inversely associated with urinary BPA in men.

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: Micro- and nano-sized plastics in zebrafish caused oxidative stress in liver indicated by SOD and catalase changes.

nodes.label: inflammation
nodes.notes: Ultrafine and micro-sized plastic particles induced pro-inflammatory responses in human lung cells and other cell models.

nodes.label: endocrine_disruption
nodes.notes: BPA, a plastic additive migrating into food and water, is associated with altered reproductive hormones and is described as an endocrine disruptor.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Site of lipid accumulation and oxidative stress after microplastic exposure.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Entry point for ingested microplastics and xenobiotics; may show inflammation and translocation to other tissues.

nodes.label: lung
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Target of inhaled airborne microplastics and site of pro-inflammatory responses in lung cell lines.

nodes.label: other
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Gills accumulate microplastics in zebrafish and other fish species.

nodes.label: other
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Male reproductive system affected by BPA-associated hormone changes in men from an infertility clinic.

nodes.label: obesity
nodes.notes: BPA exposure could contribute to obesity development by disturbing receptors in fat tissues and affecting adipose hormone regulation.

nodes.label: breast_and_prostate_cancer
nodes.notes: BPA may induce breast and prostate cancer in mammals and possibly promote similar cancers in humans.

nodes.label: male_reproductive_hormone_disruption
nodes.notes: Higher urinary BPA is inversely associated with inhibin B and estradiol:testosterone ratio in men, indicating adverse reproductive hormone status.

nodes.description: In four of 30 commonly consumed dried fish species, 36 of 61 isolated foreign particles were identified as plastic polymers in organs and flesh.

nodes.label: personal_care

nodes.notes: Microbeads in personal care products are primary microplastics; an estimated eight billion were released daily into aquatic habitats from the USA before phase-out.

nodes.label: pellets
nodes.notes: Pre-production plastic pellets used to make larger plastic items; identified as a primary microplastic source when released to the environment.

nodes.label: textiles
nodes.notes: Microfibers from textiles are identified as a major source of secondary microplastics in the marine environment.

nodes.label: tire_wear

nodes.label: industrial_process

nodes.notes: Industrial discharge and waste leakage are major pathways by which plastics enter the oceans.

nodes.assumptions_notes: Seafood consumption is identified as one pathway for human microplastic exposure; global per capita seafood consumption is over 20 kg/year, with shellfish and small fish consumed whole posing particular concern.
A top European shellfish consumer is estimated to ingest approximately 11,000 plastic particles annually via shellfish.
Microplastics detected in beer, honey, and sea salt provide additional oral exposure pathways, with salts alone contributing up to 37 particles per person per year.

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: Research on nanoparticles and microplastics reports oxidative stress in lung, liver, and brain cells, and systemic oxidative effects after oral exposure.

nodes.label: inflammation
nodes.notes: Microplastic ingestion in marine animals such as blue mussels and crabs leads to immune responses, granuloma formation, and hemocyte aggregation, suggesting inflammatory processes.

nodes.label: immune_dysregulation
nodes.notes: Predicted and observed effects of microplastic exposure include compromised immune cells and immune responses in marine organisms.

nodes.label: genotoxicity
nodes.notes: Parallel research into nanoparticles and nanoplastics indicates genotoxic responses following systemic distribution.

nodes.label: metabolic_disturbance
nodes.notes: Systemic distribution of nanoparticles from oral exposure has been associated with alterations of endogenous metabolites, nutrient absorption, and gut microflora.

nodes.name: urinary_bisphenol_A
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Urine BPA levels show a significant correlation with cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes in population studies.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.histology_notes: Primary contact site for ingested microplastics and nanoplastics; M cells and mucosa involved in uptake and translocation.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Potential site of local GI tract effects including inflammation, changes in nutrient absorption, and microbiome disruption.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.histology_notes: Receives nanoparticles and microplastics transported via blood and lymph following oral exposure.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Hepatic stress observed in fish after ingestion of polyethylene fragments; liver cells show toxicity in vitro.

nodes.label: lung
nodes.histology_notes: Epithelial tissue potentially contacted by inhaled microplastics analogous to ingestion exposure routes.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: In vitro toxicity has been observed in lung cells exposed to plastic-related nanoparticles.

nodes.label: brain
nodes.histology_notes: Protected by blood–brain barrier, which nanoparticles and nanoplastics can cross.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Nanoplastic movement across the blood–brain barrier raises concern for neurological effects and genotoxicity.

nodes.label: blood
nodes.histology_notes: Circulatory system receiving translocated microplastics and nanoplastics from gut and lungs.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Serves as transport medium to secondary organs including liver, gall bladder, brain, and placenta.

nodes.label: placenta
nodes.histology_notes: Barrier between maternal and fetal circulation.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Nanoplastics are reported to cross the placenta, raising concern for fetal exposure.

nodes.label: other
nodes.histology_notes: Represents urine as an excreted matrix used for biomonitoring of BPA.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Used to assess internal exposure to plastic-associated monomers such as BPA.

nodes.label: cardiovascular_disease
nodes.notes: A significant correlation is reported between urinary BPA concentration and cardiovascular disease in epidemiologic studies.

nodes.label: type_2_diabetes
nodes.notes: Urinary BPA levels are significantly correlated with type 2 diabetes.

nodes.label: outdoor_air_MP_concentrations
nodes.notes: Outdoor air microplastic levels 0–393 particles_per_m3; weighted mean about 194 particles_per_m3; dominated by PP and PE with other polymers present.

nodes.label: indoor_air_MP_concentrations
nodes.notes: Indoor air microplastics from 0.4 up to 1583 particles_per_m3; weighted mean about 938 particles_per_m3; higher than outdoors; dominated by fibers and fragments of PP and PE.

nodes.label: indoor_dust_MP_concentrations
nodes.notes: Indoor dust shows wide range 0.19–196000 particles_per_g; weighted mean about 727 particles_per_g when all relevant MP types considered.

nodes.label: drinking_water_MP_concentrations
nodes.notes: Tap water up to 1247 particles_per_L; bottled water ranges from tens to >6000 particles_per_L depending on packaging type; PET, PE, PP frequently detected.

nodes.label: seafood_MP_concentrations
nodes.notes: Seafood (especially Mytilus_edulis and some clams) contains from non_detected up to several thousand particles_per_kg; PP, PE, PET common polymers.

nodes.label: breast_milk_MP_concentrations
nodes.notes: Human breast milk contains 0–2.72 particles_per_g with mean around 0.53 particles_per_g; PE, PVC, and PP are most abundant.

nodes.assumptions_notes: Uses respiratory rate, tidal volume, body weight, and exposure factors (8h outdoors, 16h indoors) to estimate inhaled dose (ID).
Uses dust ingestion rates and weighted average dust concentrations to estimate dust intake (DI).
Pescatarian meal plan with seafood, milk, alcoholic beverages, and 2 L water used to estimate Estimated Daily Intake (EDI).
Uses approximate 200 mL breast milk per kg body weight per day and measured MP concentrations.

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: Contact of epithelial cells with micro- and nanoplastics can lead to oxidative stress.

nodes.label: inflammation
nodes.notes: Inflammatory responses discussed as relevant potential mechanism for inhaled and ingested microplastics.

nodes.label: lung
nodes.histology_notes: Target for inhaled airborne microplastics as part of particulate matter.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Respiratory epithelium may be affected by deposited microplastics; specific health risks still unclear.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.histology_notes: Primary interface for ingested microplastics from food, dust, and water.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Potential site of oxidative stress and barrier interactions for micro- and nanoplastics.

nodes.label: blood
nodes.histology_notes: Breast milk particles imply potential translocation from maternal circulation, but mechanisms not fully characterized.

nodes.label: respiratory_effects_from_MP_exposure
nodes.notes: Human health risks from inhaled microplastics are not yet clarified; evidence insufficient for firm conclusions.

nodes.label: systemic_effects_from_ingested_MP
nodes.notes: Total daily intake estimates exist, but links to specific clinical outcomes are not established.

nodes.name: Polystyrene
nodes.notes: Commercially synthesized polystyrene microplastics used in most rodent and cell toxicity studies.

nodes.name: Polyethylene
nodes.notes: Polyethylene microplastics applied in rodent and cell studies and present in environmental and airborne microplastics.

nodes.name: Polypropylene
nodes.notes: Inhalable indoor plastic fibers of polypropylene nature reported in indoor air.

nodes.name: Polyvinyl chloride
nodes.notes: Carcinogenic polymer mentioned as composed of monomers with severe bioeffects.

nodes.label: fiber
nodes.definition_notes: Elongated particles with high aspect ratio; commonly reported in indoor air, lung tissue, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, colon tissue, and feces.
nodes.artifact_notes: Long plastic fibers (>1000 μm) show higher penetration ability in respiratory tract.

nodes.label: fragment
nodes.definition_notes: Irregular broken plastic pieces frequently observed in feces, liver, spleen and environmental samples.

nodes.label: film
nodes.definition_notes: Thin flat plastic pieces detected in human feces.

nodes.label: bead
nodes.definition_notes: Spherical microplastics used in personal care products and dermal exposure studies.

nodes.label: fecal_microplastics_20_4813um
nodes.definition_notes: Size range of microplastics reported in human feces.

nodes.label: indoor_air_microplastics_30_3000um
nodes.definition_notes: Dominant suspended atmospheric microplastics size range in indoor and urban air; many are fibers.

nodes.label: nanoplastics_20_100nm
nodes.definition_notes: Nanoplastics less than 100 nm implicated in dermal penetration and cellular uptake.

nodes.label: drink_microplastics_100_3000um
nodes.definition_notes: Size range (0.1–3 mm) of microplastics reported in soft drinks, cold teas, and energy drinks.

nodes.label: textiles
nodes.notes: Synthetic textiles identified as one of the most important sources of primary microplastics, shedding fibers to indoor air and dust.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: City dust noted as an important source of primary microplastics.

nodes.label: personal_care
nodes.notes: Microbeads and other plastic particles in hand cleansers, facial/body scrubs, face masks, and toothpaste.

nodes.label: lung
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Main destination of inhaled microplastics; contains plastic fibers in lung tissue and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Receives ingested microplastics; site of mucus barrier, intestinal microbiota and barrier function disruption.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Accumulation of fragmented microplastics (<30 μm). Higher levels in cirrhotic liver than healthy liver.

nodes.label: kidney
nodes.vulnerability_notes: No microplastics detected in examined kidney tissue in the cited study.

nodes.label: placenta
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Microplastics detected in human placenta, indicating maternal transfer to fetus.

nodes.label: brain
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Target of nanoplastic neurotoxicity; decreased acetylcholinesterase activity and altered cognitive function in mice.

nodes.label: blood
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Contains microplastics >700 nm at measurable mass concentrations, indicating systemic circulation of particles.

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: Microplastics induce oxidative stress evidenced by ROS overproduction, increased malondialdehyde, decreased antioxidant levels, mitochondrial depolarization and damage.

nodes.label: inflammation
nodes.notes: Ingestion of polystyrene microplastics causes intestinal inflammation, disturbance of intestinal barrier, decreased mucin secretion, and altered gut microbiota.

nodes.label: endocrine_disruption
nodes.notes: Dermal exposure to monomers and plasticizers such as phthalates and bisphenols released from microplastics; these are recognized endocrine disruptors.

nodes.label: genotoxicity
nodes.notes: Nanoplastics localize near chromosomes, induce DNA-related gene expression changes and genotoxicity in cell models.

nodes.label: immune_dysregulation
nodes.notes: Microplastics alter hematopoiesis and immune cell populations, including decreased leukocytes and lymphocytes and increased neutrophils.

nodes.label: metabolic_disturbance
nodes.notes: Microplastics disrupt energy homeostasis and hepatic lipid metabolism; anaerobic metabolism and lactate dehydrogenase activation with reduced ATP production observed.

nodes.name: Reactive oxygen species (ROS)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Overproduction of ROS reflects mitochondrial damage and oxidative stress induced by microplastics.
citations_ref: Sun & Wang (2023) Human Exposure to Microplastics and Its Associated Health Risks

nodes.name: Malondialdehyde
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Lipid peroxidation marker increased in reproductive toxicity studies of microplastics.

nodes.name: Lactate dehydrogenase activity
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Activation associated with anaerobic metabolism and reduced ATP production under microplastics exposure.

nodes.name: Succinate dehydrogenase activity
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Loss of activity reported in reproductive toxicity linked to metabolic enzyme disruption.

nodes.name: Acetylcholinesterase activity
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased activity in mouse brain associated with nanoplastic-induced neurotoxicity.

nodes.name: IRE1-α protein expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Overexpression reflects endoplasmic reticulum stress after polyethylene nanoplastic exposure in macrophage-like cells.

nodes.name: BiP protein expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Component of endoplasmic reticulum stress response upregulated by polyethylene nanoplastics.

nodes.name: CHOP protein expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: ER-stress-associated protein upregulated in response to polyethylene nanoplastic exposure.

nodes.label: gut_barrier_dysfunction
nodes.notes: Microplastics ingestion leads to intestinal inflammation, decreased mucin secretion, barrier disturbance and altered microflora in mice.

nodes.label: reproductive_toxicity
nodes.notes: Decreased testosterone, reduced sperm number and motility, sperm deformation and ovarian granulosa cell apoptosis and fibrosis in rodents exposed to microplastics.

nodes.label: immune_system_alteration
nodes.notes: Changes in leukocyte, lymphocyte and neutrophil counts and bone marrow gene expression following ingestion or inhalation of microplastics.

nodes.label: neurobehavioral_changes
nodes.notes: Locomotor activity decrease, anxiety-like behavior and cognitive function changes observed in mice exposed to micro- and nanoplastics.

nodes.label: liver_cirrhosis_with_microplastics
nodes.notes: Higher concentration of microplastics detected in cirrhotic liver compared to healthy liver; association but not causal link.

nodes.label: inflammatory_bowel_disease_with_microplastics
nodes.notes: Higher fecal microplastics content in patients with inflammatory bowel disease relative to healthy individuals.

nodes.title: Microplastics in drinking-water
nodes.scope: Assessment of microplastics in drinking water and potential human health risks.
nodes.notes: World Health Organization report stating no proof of harmful effects in drinking water but highlighting need for more research.

nodes.title: Dietary and inhalation exposure to nano- and microplastic particles and potential implications for human health
nodes.scope: Review of dietary and inhalation exposure to microplastics and nanoplastics and potential health implications.
nodes.notes: WHO report summarizing exposure via diet and inhalation.

nodes.assumptions_notes: Includes seafood, table salt, tap water, bottled water and processed drinks as sources of ingested microplastics.
Includes inhalation of airborne microplastic fibers in indoor, urban and rural air.
Dermal penetration mainly relevant for nanoplastics and for endocrine-disrupting monomers and plasticizers released from products.

nodes.notes: Human fecal samples with up to 138.9 items/g microplastics, high positive rate and multiple shapes and polymer types.
Feces of patients with inflammatory bowel disease with higher microplastics content (~41.8 items/g).
Feces of healthy individuals with lower microplastics content (~28 items/g) compared to IBD patients.
Human lung tissue containing plastic fibers mostly within 500 μm, up to 2.84 items/g.
Cirrhotic human liver samples with increased microplastics concentration (~11.9 items/g).
Healthy human liver samples with <1.9 items/g microplastics.
Human blood samples containing microplastics over 700 nm at ~1.6 μg/mL.
Placental tissue containing plastic fragments within 10 μm.
Meconium samples from newborns containing multiple types of microplastics.
Human breastmilk samples with small plastic fragments (2–12 μm) in >76% of samples.
Tap water containing ~4.2 items/L microplastics.
Bottled water with higher microplastics levels (~94 items/L) and smaller particle sizes than groundwater-based tap water.
Indoor air samples with 19.6 fibers/m3 polypropylene fibers and ~1583 MPs/m3 total microplastics.
Urban outdoor air with ~224 MPs/m3 and larger fiber fractions.
Rural outdoor air with ~101 MPs/m3.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_human_feces
nodes.note: Includes fragments, films, and fibers; sizes 20–4813 μm and >15 plastic types with 95.8% sample positivity.

nodes.label: fecal_mps_ibd_vs_healthy
nodes.note: Higher fecal microplastics in inflammatory bowel disease patients (~41.8 items/g) than healthy controls (~28 items/g).

nodes.label: microplastics_in_lung_tissue
nodes.note: Plastic fibers mostly <500 μm detected in human lung tissue.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_liver_cirrhosis
nodes.note: Cirrhotic liver showing higher microplastic burden than healthy liver.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_human_blood
nodes.note: Microplastics over 700 nm detected in human blood indicating systemic circulation.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_placenta
nodes.note: Plastic fragments within 10 μm detected in human placentas, indicating maternal transfer.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_meconium
nodes.note: Ten types of microplastics identified in meconium, suggesting prenatal exposure.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_breastmilk
nodes.note: Small plastic fragments (2–12 μm) present in >76% of human breastmilk samples.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_tap_water
nodes.note: Tap water microplastics concentration with larger particle sizes (50–150 μm) in groundwater-derived sources.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_bottled_water
nodes.note: Bottled water has ~20-fold higher microplastics concentrations than tap water, with sizes 6.5–20 μm.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_indoor_air
nodes.note: Indoor air microplastics loading with 19.6 polypropylene fibers/m3 and overall high suspended MPs.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_urban_air
nodes.note: Urban outdoor air microplastics, including large fibers up to ~2191 μm.

nodes.label: microplastics_in_rural_air
nodes.note: Rural outdoor air microplastics with lower abundance than urban air.
