attributes.name: polyethylene
attributes.notes: Predominant polymer in liver, kidney and especially brain microplastics; ~75% of polymer mass in brain samples on average.

attributes.name: polypropylene
attributes.notes: Polymer whose concentrations increased from 2016 to 2024 in liver and brain.
Single-shot pyrolysis gas chromatography–mass spectrometry used to quantify 12 specific polymers in KOH-digested tissue pellets.
Attenuated total reflectance–Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy applied to confirm polymer composition (especially PE) in a subset of brain samples.
Scanning electron microscopy with energy-dispersive spectroscopy used to visualize carbon-rich particles and distinguish them from mineral or metallic inclusions.
Transmission electron microscopy of dispersed pellets resolved shard- or flake-like nanoplastics typically <200 nm in length and <40 nm in width.
Polarization wave microscopy used to detect refractile inclusions in histological sections of liver, kidney and brain.

attributes.definition_notes: Operational size range for microplastics and nanoplastics (MNPs) defined in the study.
Rod-shaped particles in liver and kidney tissues observed in the 1–5 µm size range.
Shard-like particles isolated from KOH-insoluble pellets typically less than 0.4 µm in length.
Nanoplastics in brain pellets described as largely 100–200 nm in length.
Shard- or flake-like solid particulates observed by TEM in liver, kidney and brain pellets.
Rod-shaped microplastic particles observed in liver lipid droplet regions and kidney structures around 1–5 µm.

attributes.histology_notes: Frontal cortex; dementia cases show notable deposition in cerebrovascular walls and immune cell-rich regions.
attributes.vulnerability_notes: Contains blood–brain barrier; dementia cases characterized by impaired barrier integrity and poor clearance mechanisms.

attributes.histology_notes: Liver particulates widely dispersed and aggregated within acellular regions consistent with lipid droplets.
Elevated presence of refractile inclusions in glomeruli and along tubules.

attributes.assumptions_notes: Hypothesized pathway: ingestion of lipids facilitates selective transfer of nanoplastics from intestine to brain; proposed by analogy to Daphnia magna uptake and not directly measured in this study.

attributes.notes: Brain sections from dementia cases show refractile inclusions in regions with immune cell accumulation and along vascular walls, consistent with localized inflammation; association only, no causal role established.

attributes.population: decedent adults with Alzheimer’s disease, vascular dementia and other dementias
attributes.notes: Decedent brains with documented dementia diagnosis exhibit greater accumulation of MNPs than brains from participants without dementia; study explicitly states that these data are associative and do not establish a causal role.

nodes.label: Total MNPs and polymer composition in liver 2016 cohort

attributes.notes: Baseline liver polymer concentrations measured by Py-GC/MS in 2016 cohort; lower than 2024 liver and lower than brain concentrations.

nodes.label: Total MNPs and polymer composition in liver 2024 cohort

attributes.notes: Median total plastics concentration 433 µg g−1; includes PE, PP, PVC, SBR and other polymers, with higher levels than 2016.

nodes.label: Total MNPs and polymer composition in kidney 2016 cohort

attributes.notes: Baseline kidney polymer concentrations measured by Py-GC/MS in 2016 cohort; similar order of magnitude as liver but lower than brain.

nodes.label: Total MNPs and polymer composition in kidney 2024 cohort

attributes.notes: Median total plastics concentration 404 µg g−1 in 2024 kidney samples; polymer mixture similar to liver.

nodes.label: Total MNPs and polymer composition in brain 2016 New Mexico cohort

attributes.notes: Median brain MNP concentration 3345 µg g−1 (25–75%: 1,267–5,213 µg g−1); higher than liver and kidney; PE ~75% of polymer mass.

nodes.label: Total MNPs and polymer composition in brain 2024 New Mexico cohort

attributes.notes: Median brain MNP concentration 4,917 µg g−1 (25–75%: 4,026–5,608 µg g−1); significantly higher than 2016 and higher than liver and kidney; PE dominant (~75% of polymer mass).

nodes.label: Total MNPs and localization in dementia brains (New Mexico)

attributes.notes: Dementia cases show median total plastics 26,076 µg g−1, greater than any normal frontal cortex cohort; inclusions localized in cerebrovascular walls and immune cell-rich regions.

nodes.label: Total MNPs and polymer composition in East Coast brains 1997–2013

attributes.notes: East Coast brain samples (1997–2013) exhibit lower median total plastics (1,254 µg g−1) compared with more recent New Mexico cohorts; used in linear regression of temporal trends.

nodes.name: polyethylene
nodes.notes: Most frequently detected polymer in human kidney and urine samples in this study.

nodes.name: polystyrene
nodes.notes: Frequently detected polymer in human kidney and urine samples and in prior human tissue studies.

nodes.name: styrene–isoprene copolymer
nodes.notes: Detected as a red particle in urine sample (U4), likely a plastic micro-fragment derived from a styrene–isoprene copolymer or its pigment.
Ten urine samples from healthy individuals were collected (250–300 mL each) and digested in 10% KOH prior to microRaman analysis.
Ten healthy portions of human kidneys (1–4 g each) obtained from nephrectomies were collected and digested in 10% KOH prior to microRaman analysis.

nodes.label: 1–5 µm
nodes.definition_notes: Lower portion of the size range of microplastic and pigment particles detected in kidney and urine (down to ~1 µm).

nodes.label: 5–15 µm
nodes.definition_notes: Typical size range of many microplastic particles in urine (3–13 µm) and kidneys.

nodes.label: 15–30 µm
nodes.definition_notes: Upper portion of the size range of microplastic and pigment particles detected in kidneys (up to 29 µm).

nodes.label: fragment
nodes.definition_notes: Includes irregular microplastic fragments and pigment particles detected on PTFE filters after digestion.

nodes.label: fiber
nodes.definition_notes: Red fiber (styrene–isoprene) label used in reference library; in the study, the corresponding particle in urine (U4) was likely a short fragment with fiber-like reference spectrum.

nodes.label: kidney
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Highly vascularized organ receiving about one-fifth of cardiac output and responsible for waste removal; likely participates in microplastic handling and deposition.

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: Polystyrene microplastics induce renal oxidative stress with histological changes and functional alterations in juvenile rats and mice, contributing to kidney damage.

nodes.label: inflammation
nodes.notes: Polystyrene microplastics increase inflammatory mediators and inflammatory infiltration in kidney tissue, contributing to tubular and glomerular damage.

nodes.label: kidney_damage_and_function_alteration
nodes.population: animal_model (juvenile rats and mice exposed to polystyrene microplastics)
nodes.notes: Renal histological changes (inflammatory infiltration, tubular and glomerular damage) and alterations in kidney function observed after polystyrene microplastic exposure in experimental animals.

nodes.assumptions_notes: After ingestion of contaminated food and water, microplastics enter blood and lymphatic systems and accumulate in kidney, liver, and brain; microplastics are then partially excreted in urine.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Polyethylene is used in water and soft drink bottles, water tanks, and plastic wraps; polystyrene is used in food packaging and disposable beverage containers, acting as secondary sources of microplastics that can contaminate food and water.

nodes.label: lung
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Microplastics have been detected in autopsy and surgically resected human lung tissue and in bronchoalveolar lavage samples, indicating that inhaled particles can reach deep regions of the lung filecite2L15-L40
citations_ref: Amato-Lourenço et al. 2021 presence of airborne microplastics in human lung tissue
Jenner et al. 2022 detection of microplastics in human lung tissue using FTIR spectroscopy
Baeza-Martínez et al. 2022 microplastics in bronchoalveolar lavage from European citizens

nodes.name: altered_cell_metabolism_and_adhesion
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Laboratory in vitro and animal model studies report that microplastic exposure alters cell metabolism and adhesion in respiratory cells, suggesting early mechanistic changes relevant for lung pathology filecite2L40-L80
citations_ref: Goodman et al. 2021 exposure of human lung cells to polystyrene microplastics
Xu et al. 2019 effects of nanoplastic particles on human lung epithelial cells

nodes.name: apoptosis_related_protein_expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Changes in the expression of proteins associated with apoptosis have been observed after exposure to nanoplastic particles in human lung epithelial cells filecite2L40-L80
citations_ref: Xu et al. 2019 internalization and toxicity of nanoplastic particles in human lung epithelial cells

nodes.notes: Polyester and nylon fiber processing in occupational settings is associated with respiratory symptoms including cough, dyspnea, and wheezing filecite2L80-L120

nodes.label: reduced_lung_function

nodes.notes: Environmental microplastics in human respiratory specimens have been linked with reduced lung function metrics filecite2L80-L120

nodes.label: bronchial_obstruction
citations_ref: Reports of environmental microplastics associated with bronchial obstruction
nodes.notes: Environmental microplastics detected in human respiratory specimens are associated with bronchial obstruction filecite2L80-L120

nodes.label: inflammation
nodes.notes: Laboratory research with in vitro and animal models, together with occupational health observations, indicates that microplastics can promote inflammatory responses in the respiratory system filecite2L40-L80
citations_ref: Goodman et al. 2021 polystyrene microplastics effects on human lung cells

nodes.label: metabolic_disturbance
nodes.notes: In vitro and animal models show that microplastic exposure can alter cell metabolism and adhesion in respiratory cells, consistent with metabolic disturbance filecite2L40-L80

nodes.label: other

citations_ref: Xu et al. 2019 nanoplastic particle effects on human lung epithelial cells

nodes.assumptions_notes: Editorial notes that inhalation may be the primary route by which microplastics enter the body, with indoor inhalation of airborne microfibers potentially exceeding dietary intake during a meal filecite2L40-L80
citations_ref: Sridharan et al. 2021 microplastics as emerging particulate air pollution
Dris et al. 2017 textile fibers including microplastics in indoor and outdoor environments

nodes.assumptions_notes: Occupational settings with polyester, nylon, and polypropylene fiber processing lead to inhalation of synthetic microfibers linked to respiratory symptoms and interstitial lung disease filecite2L80-L120
citations_ref: Occupational polyester and nylon fiber processing studies
Atis et al. 2005 occupational polypropylene flock exposure

nodes.label: tire_wear
nodes.notes: In cities, microplastics from tire wear and tear alone account for up to 8.5 percent of PM10 and 10 percent of PM2.5, indicating a major secondary microplastic source to urban air filecite2L40-L80

nodes.label: textiles
nodes.notes: Plastic microfibers derived from synthetic clothing contribute substantially to airborne indoor and outdoor microplastics; textile fibers have been documented in indoor and outdoor atmospheric fallout and dust filecite2L40-L80

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Plastics accumulate in landfills and the environment where they break down into microplastics; single use plastics increased during the COVID 19 pandemic, contributing to airborne microplastic exposure filecite2L1-L40
